elements.text: Hi everyone, it's nice to see that there is interest in another book club! I think it would be good to time this for the first half of 2024. This gives us some time to organize and promote it and for people to plan it into their schedules. We also have tentative plans for developer days at useR! 2024 (July) and posit::conf(2024) (August), so it could work well as preparation for that. We struggled a bit with the original timetable (as on

), partly because of the amount of material and partly because the book was quite a challenging read (often a lot of new concepts at once, that are not well paired with exercises to help understanding). So I think we would want to do something a bit different.

Here are some possible options:

Spread the Modern C material over 26 weeks (13 sessions every 2 weeks vs 8 sessions every 2 weeks last time).
This will giving more opportunity to digest the material and work on related practice problems (possibly from elsewhere). Suggested timetable:
1: ch 1-2 - compiling and running, basic structure of a program
2: ch 3 - flow control
3: ch 4 - operators (arithmetic, logical)
4: ch 5 sec 1-5 - basic values and data types
5: ch 5 sec 6-7 - named constants and binary representation
6: ch 6 - arrays and pointers
7: ch 7, 9, 10 - functions, style, organization and documentation
8: ch 8 - C library functions
9: ch 11 - pointers in more depth
10: ch 12 - C memory model
11: ch 13 - storage
12: ch 14 - more involved processing an I/O
+ 1 session on ch 14 of Deep R Programming (

) on R' C API.
Sessions could be participants presenting the material, as before, or presenting related practice problems they have worked on.
The C sessions of CS50, Harvard's Introduction to Compute Science (

). 1 session a month.
Several participants preferred this material to the Modern C book. It might not go in so much depth, but may be a better introduction. There are well integrated practice problems and labs, plus dedicated help forums. People would have the option to continue study and obtain a certificate via EdX (~$200, financial assistance available).
Month 1: C basics
Month 2: Arrays
Month 3: Algorithms
Month 4: Memory
Month 5: Data Structures
This could be paired with
Month 0: Scratch, for people wanting to take the full course or

Month 6: ch 14 of Deep R Programming.
Suggested work pattern:
Week 1: watch lecture (2.5 hr)
Week 2: watch shorts (6 x 10-15 min videos that expand on topics in the lecture) and do one or more practice problems
Week 3: do the lab
Week 4: meet to share solutions to the lab. Do problem set and submit if doing full course.

). 1 session a month.
This would be about how to contribute to the R project vs learning C. Throwing this in as a wild card option!
Month 1: (ch 1 & 2) Bug-tracking/reporting
Month 2: (ch 3) Bug reviewing
Month 3: (ch 8) Documentation and simple patches
Month 4: (ch 5) Life cycle of a patch
Month 5: (ch 2) Building R
Month 6: (ch 9/10) Testing R/Translation
We could pair reading the chapters with examples/exercises we have done before in the Collaborative Campfires/other outreach sessions. Would take a little more work to pull together, but could help build a better set of resources for self-study/future study groups.

What do you think? Express you preference via emoji vote!
Weeks 1-5 of CS50 + Scratch added at the start
Weeks 1-5 of CS50 + R' C API at the end
